newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: FOCUS-S.Africa wins second investment grade rating.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-S.Africa wins second investment grade rating.

text.p: South Africa on Wednesday won its second investment grade credit rating from a U.S.-accredited agency, signalling growing confidence in the country and paving the way for a major dollar bond issue.
Duff & Phelps Credit Rating Co said it had assigned an investment grade BBB minus rating to the country's foreign currency debt, matching the assessment of Moody's Investors Service Inc.

The Ministry of Finance said the rating was significant given that certain U.S. investors, such as insurance funds, were restricted in terms of their investments when a country did not have two investment grade ratings from U.S.-accredited agencies.
The move comes ahead of South Africa's second Yankee bond issue, expected in the next few weeks, which dealers say is likely to raise around $500 million.

"We can access a wider array of capital sources in the United States, and we think this is good for South Africa's future Yankees," Finance Minister Trevor Manuel told reporters during a visit to Tokyo.
Analysts welcomed the news which they said also augured well for an upgrade from influential agency Standard and Poor's Corp later this year.

"It's a good indication. The importance really is that it suggests there might be an upgrade from the more important credit rating agencies," said Nico Czypionka, chief economist at Standard Bank in Johannesburg.

South Africa's long-term foreign currency debt currently straddles investment grade. Moody's Investors Service Inc rates the country an investment grade prospect at Baa3. But S&P has it pegged one notch below at BB plus.

S&P is expected to visit South Africa around September or October and Guido Cipriani, S&P director responsible for South Africa, told Reuters in May that prospects had improved since the agency's last visit in September 1996.

Mike Brown, chief economist at SocGen Frankel Pollak, is confident of an S&P upgrade following a cut in the 1997/98 budget deficit, a recent sharp rise in foreign reserves and important exchange control relaxation effective from July 1.
"I'd be surprised if they don't upgrade us," Brown said.

"I think we've met the monetary and fiscal targets, we've got the reserves and we are dismantling exchange controls. We are basically there -- our only element of risk is crime and violence, and I'm not sure how they will mark us on that."

Duff & Phelps said its rating view reflected the strong commitment of the government to establish a competitive and creditworthy economy, backed up by its medium-term Growth, Employment and Redistribution (Gear) strategy.
However, the rating was constrained by continued high fiscal deficits, low domestic savings, high unemployment, still relatively low reserves and high crime rates.

IBCA, the only other agency to have rated South Africa in the last two years, currently has the country on a speculative BB. A company official said on Wednesday that IBCA was unlikely to review this rating until November or December.
